WorkItem.ClosedComment: This works as designed. If the Task Scheduler service is not running, when you try to register a task, you will get an error indicating so.
WorkItem.Description:
Envirinment: Windows 7 64-bit, TaskScheduler library release version 1.4.2
Repro steps:
1. Disable Task Scheduler service in Windows 7 through the registry
2. Run test application and create TaskService service = new TaskService();
3. Check service.Connected property is "true" though the service is really disabled
4. Also probably some other properties has wrong values, eg. HighestSupportedVersion = 1.1, but v1TaskScheduler is null and v2 equals "true" and v2TaskService is NOT null.
Â 
So I didn't find a way how to detect that the service is stopped in Windows 7.
WorkItem.Summary: TaskService.Connected property has wrong value when Task scheduler service is disabled
